title: Dartmoor Ramble Walking Route

images.title: Derek Harper / Bellever Tor
images.caption: Bellever Tor. This is the main eastern mass of the tor, which has splendid views in all directions and is an easy climb only about a kilometre from two car parks. On the left is a glimpse of Laughter Tor to the southeast.

images.title: Rob Purvis / Grey Wethers stone circles
images.caption: Grey Wethers stone circles

images.title: Richard Knights / Hangingstone Hill - Dartmoor
images.caption: Hangingstone Hill - Dartmoor. Hangingstone Hill is bang in the middle of North Dartmoor and is a good place to start exploring the wilderness. It is a high exposed point (603m) at SX 617862 which is visible from many other parts of the moor. There is no tor - just an army observation station - but the views on a mist free day are superb. The name Hangingstone derives from a logan rock (or rocking stone) that is on the NW slope of the hill. Alas the rock no longer rocks.

images.title: Christopher Clift / Grimspound Dartmoor
images.caption: The picture is of the entrance into Grimspound on Dartmoor. This one of many pictures of Grimspound. However get the children to look for the small incised cross carved on the bottom boulder on the right. It has been there for as many years I have visited the site.

images.title: Guy Wareham / Soussons Down stone circle
images.caption: Soussons Down stone circle. Twenty-two stones surrounding the remains of a burial chamber of which only two side slabs remain visible.

description: A wonderful circular walk around the fascinating Dartmoor National Park with plenty of lovely riverside walking and some challenging climbs. The walk starts near the car park at Bellever and first follows the East Dart River through Postbridge and on to Sittaford Tor where you will pass the historical Grey Wethers Stone Circle. Challenging climbs on Whitehorse Hill and Hangingstone Hill follow, offering fabulous views of Dartmoor and the surrounding areas. The walk continues past Oke Tor to the town of Okehampton where you will pass the ruins of the 11th century Okehampton Castle. You then join the East Okemont River and the River Taw for two pleasant waterside stretches which lead you to the little village of Sticklepath. From here you head south towards Teigncombe where you join the River Teign for another riverside section which passes Chagford and the Wooton Castle Iron Age Hill fort before reaching the delightful Meadhaydown Wood Nature Reserve. The route then turns west towards Moretonhampstead (notable for having the longest one-word name of any place in England), the fine Bovey Castle hotel and then the fascinating Grimspound Bronze Age settlement which consists of a set of 24 hut circles surrounded by a low stone wall. The final section takes you past the wooded Soussons Down to the finish point back at Bellever.
